titleStmt.title: Proverbs: from Nibru -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

notesStmt.note: This file includes all manuscripts from Nibru which it has not been possible to assign to the proverb collections numbered in modern editions. The manuscripts are presented in decreasing order of size. Some of the proverbs are duplicated in numbered collections.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

div1.p: &X;&X; his hand &X;&X;.

&X;&X; the go-between's fee &X;&X; lion &X;&X;
&X;&X; not &X;&X; wife &X;&X;
Get on with (?) your assigned work!

&X;&X; more than a house &X;&X; field &X;&X;. The dragon doesn't &X;&X; its rival. In building a house &X;&X;
&X;&X; of the strong man. &X;&X; its roar, the lion won't cease &X;&X;.
&X;&X; follow the merchant.
The palace's water is coming out &X;&X;.
&X;&X; not &X;&X; to the house. He will not found a city.
&X;&X; meadow grass is the milk of a lettuce.
A reed worker &X;&X; the breast of a storm &X;&X; are many.
&X;&X; butting against &X;&X;.

cf. Ni 9824 Seg. B ll. 3-5, 6.1.09.d4, 6.2.3: UET 6/2 315 ll. 10-13
Because of my silver, because of my gold, because of my money chest, because of my &X;&X; chest, I am finished.
&X;&X; good &X;&X; eat &X;&X;.
Release the &X;&X;! He will not provide the food supply.
The donkey of An&c;an, the bear (?) of Mar&h;a&c;i, the cat of Melu&h;a, the elephant of the eastern mountains, bite off Euphrates poplars as if they were leeks.
A pickaxe put in the &X;&X; clay is a mongoose in its city.
In a complaint, half a gur from the desert &X;&X; seized like a lord &X;&X;.
He cannot &X;&X; in his hand. He does not listen &X;&X;. He scratches on the ground.
A courtesan who &X;&X; in the streets &X;&X; doesn't give &X;&X; to a fallen man.
Like a wild ass which has put &X;&X;.
He who rubbed (?) his nose against a beer vat or a large beer container (?) &X;&X;.
cf. 6.1.01.40, 6.1.19.f4 Let &X;&X; be &X;&X;. Let his bread be foul food. No man should eat it.

cf. 6.1.03.31, 6.1.09.b1, 6.1.11.18, 6.1.15.b8, 6.1.25.4 He captured Simurrum but did not destroy its walls. He built E-ana but then abandoned it. He did not see mighty kingship. Thus Nanni was carried off to the nether world despondent.
&X;&X; someone &X;&X; the mounds.
Why &X;&X;?
cf. 6.1.13.27 &X;&X; accept &X;&X; one-third &X;&X;.
&X;&X; no-one &X;&X;.
cf. 6.1.01.95 &X;&X; you are not a man.
&X;&X; seek out &X;&X;.
On his returning &X;&X;.
Like a &X;&X; he won't return to his house.
&X;&X; a strong man.
&X;&X; he rolled &X;&X;.
&X;&X; cut it &X;&X; you will be ill.
&X;&X; bought &X;&X;. &X;&X; dead &X;&X;.
&X;&X; open &X;&X;
cf. 6.1.02.1, 6.1.07.1, 6.2.3: UET 6/2 356 ll. 3-8 You should not eradicate their place in the universe. You should not move the oxen from their places!
cf. 6.1.02.83 An ox is walking around (?); a mace is &X;&X;.
cf. 6.1.02.4 I looked into the water. My destiny was drifting past.
cf. N 4248 Seg. A ll. 8-13, 6.1.09.d4, 6.2.3: UET 6/2 315 ll. 10-13 &X;&X; because of &X;&X;. &X;&X; because of &X;&X; I am finished.
cf. 6.1.03.42, 6.1.22: ll. 278-279, 6.2.5: YBC 8713 l. 7 If there is a dispute at the mill, a slave girl reveals (?) what she has stolen.
&X;&X; my &X;&X;. Let there be &X;&X;. &X;&X; my heart.
cf. 6.1.03.45, 6.1.07.43 &X;&X; finger. You are forever pushing like a millstone torn out of its joint.

body.head: N 6119 (Alster 1997 p. 292) and N 4047 (Veldhuis 2000 fig. 8)
body.p: What is &X;&X; your mockery to me? &X;&X; whatever he will do &X;&X; to my accounts.
Come on, clown! Just for once, say: &X;&X; my hips are heavier than 50 mana weight.
A clown made fun of the city. They made fun of him and he wept.

div1.p: cf. 6.1.02.59-60 The vixen quenched her thirst but still her motherly teats were dry. Each fox is even more &X;&X; than its mother.
cf. 6.1.02.61, 6.2.5: P 374 If the hearing of the fox &X;&X;.

body.head: Ni 4338 + 4340 (Alster 1997 pp. 294-295)
body.p: &X;&X; when his &X;&X; looks around, who &X;&X; child? &X;&X; without &X;&X; raise &X;&X;.
&X;&X; sit &X;&X; his hands for me. I will &X;&X;. How can I &X;&X;? &X;&X; make it strong for you &X;&X; make it strong &X;&X;

body.head: Ni 4122 (Alster 1997 p. 293)
body.p:
cf. 6.1.03.8 To spit without covering it up with dust, to kiss with the tongue at midday without providing shade,
are abominations to the god &X;&X;.

div1.p: cf. 6.1.02.6 My fate is her voice: my mother can change it.

body.head: Ni 5327 (Alster 1997 pp. 296-297)
body.p: cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 247 The &X;&X; bird &X;&X; town square &X;&X;.
The &X;&X; bird &X;&X; may it &X;&X; my &X;&X;
The &X;&X; bird &X;&X;

body.head: Ni 4099 (Alster 1997 p. 293)
body.p: &X;&X; the workers &X;&X; young men &X;&X;.
&X;&X; you &X;&X;.
&X;&X; yours.

body.head: N 3059 (Alster 1997 p. 430)
body.p: &X;&X; no-one has &X;&X;.
&X;&X; a modest wife &X;&X;.
&X;&X; he will cause a fight &X;&X;

body.head: N 5225 (Alster 1997 pp. 291-292)
body.p: &X;&X; ploughing &X;&X; not &X;&X; a gur.
Let great men stir up the conflict for lesser men to fight out.
The little fellow loves his mother; an older brother &X;&X; an older brother. The man in charge of the offerings (?) &X;&X; a proper (?) offering.

body.head: Ni 5271 (Alster 1997 p. 296)
body.p: &X;&X; that smells, really smells.
&X;&X; smells, cheese of the anus.
&X;&X;, one born into debt (?).
&X;&X; who sleeps &X;&X; of the fire.

body.head: N 7577 + N 7578 (Veldhuis 2000 fig. 10)
body.p: &X;&X; my god's heart &X;&X;

body.head: Ni 3981 (Alster 1997 p. 293)
body.p: Prayer has given birth to his life.
Where &X;&X; you &X;&X;. Where &X;&X; you &X;&X;. The son of the just man lies hungry.

body.head: CBS 12666 (Veldhuis 2000 fig. 3)
body.p: &X;&X; died.

body.head: N 1905 (Alster 1997 pl. 114)
body.p: plotted &X;&X;.

body.head: CBS 14213 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: You &X;&X; a single instruction: Let me please your heart, let me &X;&X; my strength!

body.head: IM 58660 = 3N-T 731 (Alster 1997 p. 305)
body.p: Thus speaks a widow, a man's junior wife: What can widows become? They cannot be principal wives!

body.head: N 5569 (Veldhuis 2000 p. 395)
body.p: Do not be hostile to the weakling; do not cry for the strong one. To the craftsman his arm &X;&X;.

body.head: CBS 3811 (Alster 1997 p. 303)
body.p: The ox has broken its sinews and is lying in its yoke.

body.head: CBS 5971 (Alster 1997 pl. 114)
body.p: &X;&X; drinking &X;&X;.

body.head: CBS 7968 (Alster 1997 p. 303)
body.p: I prostrate myself for the sake of Gula, my lady, but in my own eyes I don't have a place to stand.

body.head: IM 58400 = 3N-T 242 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: Don't cause the oven in a man's house to smoke. The smoke will ruin (?) the bread.

body.head: N 6194 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: Come, you are our son, even from when you did not exist!

body.head: UM 55-21-38 = 2N-T 172 (Alster 1997 p. 305)
body.p: It went up to heaven, it rose to heaven.

body.head: UM 55-21-278 = 3N-T 179 (Alster 1997 p. 305)
body.p: The fox gnashed its teeth and shook its head.

body.head: 3N-T 232 + 244 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: The ditches of the garden should not flow with water, or there will be vermin.

body.head: CBS 6551 (Alster 1997 p. 303)
body.p: Is my ox to provide milk for you?

body.head: CBS 7867 (Alster 1997 p. 303)
body.p: Like a man who eats sesame oil, his anus farts.

body.head: CBS 11372 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: Talking endlessly is what humankind has most on its mind.

body.head: N 5925 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: He wipes his bread on the pig.

body.head: UM 29-16-394 (Alster 1997 p. 305)
body.p: May the king live in his favourite city.

body.head: 3N-T 161 (Alster 1997 p. 304)
body.p: Your role in life is unknown.

body.head: 3N-T 772 = TIM 10/1 132 (Alster 1997 p. 305)
body.p: Your ox with its large horns will always return to you.
